comments.commentBody:
Why look at this through a Marxist lens? Do you really think the players care who gets to touch that silly, ugly trophy first?

From following the labor negotiations, it was clear that the players and owners had fairly equal bargaining positions and that, in most cases, there was mutual respect among the millionaires and billionaires; e.g., Jeff Saturday and Bob Kraft. If it were important, they could have made it a subject of collective bargaining.

The NFL has done a great job of creating parity. If a team has the right coaching staff and general manager, it can go from very bad to pretty good in 3-4 years.

If the NHL had the resolve to diminish the unnecessary violence, more of us down here might watch that sport and observe these primordial rituals you speak of.

Congrats to the Giants on a great victory in one of the best Super Bowls ever. My one complaint is the repellent corporatism of the NFL as reflected by the presentation of the Vince Lombardi Trophy to the team owners, perched on a pedestal while the players who sweated and fought to win the title must wait below on the turf for their turn to touch the trophy they won.
The Giant owners were gracious enough but every true fan knows the trophy should be awarded directly to the captain of the winning team, as the NHL awards the Stanley Cup. Seeing the Cup presented directly to Mark Messier, in New York and Edmonton, provided incredible moments and iconic images of unrehearsed bliss. The staged coldness of the NFL presentation pales beside the joyous, spontaneous celebrations of the athletic warriors. The NFL does almost everything right, but this is one thing they do wrong. It is time for fans and the media to demand they put the athletes first, where they belong.
The Giants pressured Brady on 37% of his drop backs.  "[V]ery little pressure"?  Hardly.

The conventional wisdom of the pundits before the game was that, for the Giants to win, their defense had to put pressure on Brady. Well guess what. The Giants defense got very little pressure on Brady, the Patriots scored only 17 points, and the Giants won! Brady was good, but in the Patriots final drive, he and his receivers faltered. In the Giants final drive, Manning and his receivers were magnificent, as they have been time and again this season. The best team won, and Manning deserved the MVP.
Yeah! Ufff, heart attack game. I'm a Jets fan, and love most NY teams. Loved 2008 Superbowl, think I suffered this one even more.  Thanks Giants!
Who would have predicted The Giants would end the season on top? Certainly not the Las Vegas odds makers.

After gong to 7-7 and being swept by Deadskins, who would've predicted the Gaints would end the season on top?

Amazing.
Both teams played well, too bad only one of them can win. Congratulations Giants!

The Wes Welker drop was the game. He makes it and Pats control the rest of the game. Also, no bounces went their way. Two fumbles- no recovery. The final hail mary could have bounced their way as well.
Sometimes luck is not with you, and it sure wasn't with the Patriots today.

Let's not forget Brady's interception in the 4th quarter.  Didn't seem huge at the time because the Giants didn't score - but they were able to take 6 minutes off the clock late in the game.  In my heart I think if there was 6 more minutes left in that game, the Patriots would have won.  Another Great Giant victory against the Patriots - Deja Blue is so true!
Well officiated except for one non-call.  A clear interference call - Not Called!

After many years of truly horrible Super  Bowl games (55-10, anyone?) most of the games during the past 12 years have been fantastic. NFL fans should feel grateful. As far as the Giants go, over the past several years they've shown an enormous amount of heart, having to go on the road to win, and actually winning. From 7-7 after 14 games this season, to winning the Super Bowl? Amazing!!!!!! And, @hamilton356, I totally agree with you. This is one of the best officiated games in memory. That the ref got Manningham's sideline catch right the first time, in real time, was incredible. Kudos to him.

What about the "tuck rule" that led to the Patriots beating the Raiders. That was a bogus play. If the Giants don't have a suspect holding call in the second quarter Bradshaw run for a first down, then they get at least a field goal. They had the Pats on the ropes. Worst case, they run off the clock and the Pats don't drive down the field.

Eli threw passes, his guys made catches. Brady threw passes, his guys dropped some. Eli didn't throw an interception, Brady did. As for the 49ers game, the guy let the ball hit his foot and Giants, well coached and always mentally prepared, jumped on the ball. Then, on the fumble, the well-coached Giants player stripped the ball. Those were legitimate plays. Every championship teams has plays like that. That's why Fantasy Football is just that. That's why they play the games, 60 minutes.

The bottom line, John, the winner is the team with the most points at the end of the game, and that was the Giants. Woulda, shoulda, coulda, is the province of losers and spoil sports.

Sorry, but that's reality, like it or not.
Agree with John from Juneau. This was not a great game.

You make it sound like Manning and the Giants didn't work hard to drive down the field after the dropped pass by Welker. Seems to me that they were very deserving of the win and in fact with the Giants blowing timeouts when they didn't need to and Bradshaw taking a TD too early, several things were going in the Pats favor...... but they still couldn't pull the win.

Nah, it wasn't the dropped pass by Welker. There are many variables to a football game and the Giants ended up better than the Pats.

If Wes Welker had caught the Brady pass that he dropped late in the fourth quarter - the kind that he caught all year - New England would have won. It was just like four years ago - before the amazing Tyree catch, one of the New England secondary - I can't remember who know - dropped an INT thrown right into his armstSo the Giants really didn't deserve either win.

And of course the Giants shouldn't have been in the Super Bowl at all, but for the amazing incompetence of one 49er substitute who gave away 14 points. (Of course New England shouldn't have been in the Super Bowl either, and was only due to an incompetent Baltimore kicker.)

Finally - why weren't the Giants given credit for a sack on New England's first play of the game? If a pass rush forces the QB into intentional grounding, with all that that entails (here, a safety), isn't that a sack?
Rush L was in the NE owner's box.
I agree.  The timeline of Brady in the locker room was very illuminating and only highlighted how the Patriots play the game.

Great win for the Giants !

Brady showed once again that he is overrated, and coach Belichik, by refusing to be interviewed after the game, showed once again his legendary lack of class.
To honor Bill Parcells, the man who ultimately responsible for this superb matchup, the game should be forever known as the TUNA Bowl.  It wouldn't have happened without him.
The playoffs are a totally different animal.  Win or go home.  Green Bay and New Orleans could not even make it to the Championship game.

Very exciting game, either team could have won it. It was the team who truly had the girt during the pressure moments that would prevail.....way to hold it together Giants. I surely had my doubts during the season, but when it matter you won, when it mattered you held tough.
When Ahmad Bradshaw couldn't make up his mind on whether to score on that last TD.  It put the Giants in the lead and one more opportunity for the Giants D to beat down on Brady again.
Nice and chewy for a Monday, I enjoyed it. I laughed at 60a, "Safari animal, informally" (RHINO), realizing the formal version must be Mr. Rhino.
Yes, paddle tennis and platform tennis are the same to me.  I'm glad I made someone laugh over my idiocy.  Thanks.
Oh, yes!  RHINOs love going on safari, but they usually dress in mufti--pith helmet and everything--so that's probably why you didn't catch on.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s5wioJUdpss
My son-in-law is Welsh and has an (to Americans) an unpronouncable name so we affectionately call him "Rhino."  He appears in xwds frequently!

I've never heard of a rhinosorus being in a safari. Have any of you ever heard of the presence of one?

Dick
Martin - I'm shocked, shocked that you would lay that interest in Playboy onto your wife!  You little rascal, you....

Grandpa, B, I kinda Bottomed out with 62A myself!

WHH

I have to basically agree, this legislation isn't about freedom of creativity, it's about "I got mine and I'm keeping it".  Wyden's and Issa's bill may be a start, but it's a shaky one. Granted, it's extremely difficult to craft legislation that would necessarily need to declare its spirit in it's black letter provisions, but the nuance of the whole topic would require it. Like drug laws that make all users and traffickers criminals, and authorities often ignore lower level offenders to catch bigger fish, I think the opportunity for governmental overreach, brow beating and bullying looms large in this venue as well. Will we wind up with yet more new agencies with yet more throngs and hordes of tight lipped agents twisting our arms to obtain plea deals? Who will pay for their uniforms, firearms, SUV's and sunglasses? Perhaps the taxes on royalties should be increased? More likely there would be an increase in "user fees" at the few "legitimate" websites looking to control and protect their monopolies. So far, SOPA and PIPA looked like opportunities to simply build more prisons. The new legislation should take it;s time, and carefully weigh all the issues. Then they'll see it can't be written.

"Content-makers would be crazy to let the Internet be stunted as a force for invention, mobilization and shared wisdom. "

No, they wouldn't. At least if by "content-makers" you are referring the recording industry and other middle men in the entertainment industry. To the contrary, those who control existing content have no interest in helping people create new content in competition with them.

The purpose of copyright, as is clearly stated in the constitution, is to encourage creativity. Accomplishing that may require some protection of copyright holders "intellectual property", but copyright law has always included limits on that protection in order to allow creativity.

But this law is not a copyright law. It is designed to protect a business model, not promote creativity. To the contrary, it is designed to force every web site that provides an opportunity for anyone to post their own new creations to police that content for copyright violations. It requires them to police links to other sites based on the content those sites provide. It requires Google to police links to that content for copyright violations. It requires hosting companies to police the sites they hose for copyright violations. In short, it is intended to shut down the distribution of competitive content by placing onerous requirements on anyone who might facilitate it.

@ANetliner
They did not drop out of the labor force. That 1.2 million came from an adjustment in the population caused by the BLS using figures from the 2010 Census. Most of the extra population was in the 55-64 group, which is less likely to work than younger groups. They didn't drop out in the last month, they simply weren't counted in the population before now.

"over a million people went off the record because they are no longer looking for jobs"

That is an important misunderstanding of the data. They timed out, they did not give up, or not necessarily. They are automatically reassigned out of the work force after one year, reclassified as long term unemployed, no matter if they are looking or not. One year out of work is long term, and they just are not counted.

If anything, they are more deserving of counting than those who have not yet gone a year unable to find work. Your phrasing suggests they themselves gave up and it is their own fault.

Good points, both the population adjustment comment and the unfortunate connotation of my original phrasing of 'dropped out'. Let me restate: the decline in the January 2012 unemployment rate is largely the artifact of an annual BLS reduction in the estimate of population, and the dropping of the long-term unemployed from the rolls.

With respect to the comment about lower labor participation in the 55-64 age brackets: some of that is the reluctance of employers to hire older workers.

Thank you for this column, Dr. Krugman.

The new jobs report is promising, but we need to remember what the 8.3% unemployment figure does not tell us about: the number of Americans who are underemployed, the number of Americans who are earning less than they did in 2008 and, as you observed, the number of Americans who have dropped out of the workforce and are no longer counted in the unemployment figures.

As a Jets fan I was cheering for the Giants. I didn't always like Tom Coughlin, but with time I have come to admire, respect and appreciate his quiet determination, discipline, and class. And I am happy for his success.

As far as our impulsive, sloppy and loudmouthed coach is concerned, I'm not sure which would have be worse: a Patriot or a Giant Super Bowl win. Well I guess a Patriot win would have been more painful. Ryan can be happy for the Giants. He could never be happy for the Patriots.

The contrast, on the one hand, of Coughlin and Belichick, with Ryan cound not be clearer. I am tired of the loudmouth. And, by the way, he doesn't appear to be a very good judge of talent, and his defense is old.
And that's when I knew we (here in Boston) were going to lose... kudos to Eli, Coughlin, the Giants and their fans - well played....
Manningham's 38 yard reception in the 4th Quarter.  That's when I knew we were going to win.

What a shame a 7 year old was given a red card which is way too young to be dealt with this harshly. You can not red card a parent, coach or spectator. They can be ejected but this ref got that wrong. Good for Beckham for speaking up but he should have addressed this with the ref quietly at the half or after the match. Sounds like this could have been handled in a much more constructive way without resorting to these punishments intended for adults or older kids.

When the G-men got to the 20 on the winning drive.  Until that point, the pessimist in me had me thinking this just wasn't going to be their night, but when they got within safe field goal range, I realized that they just might win the game.  Then I started getting very nervous, and the game got really interesting.

Manningham's reception was a great, great clutch moment -- a perfect pass and great catch. The contrast with the Pats' offensive weakness down the stretch made it all the more gratifying.

BUT, the unforgettable play of the game had to be Bradshaw's TD; the Pats allowing him to score, his catching on at the last second and either inability to stop himself, or to make up his mind, the realization all around that Brady had a minute to work with still. I've never seen anything like that.

Great win for a great team and most of all a great quarterback.
